posts.cooked:
When my team was first getting swerve together we wanted to do it as quick as possible, so we copied some code from another team. It’s not been a year, and we’ve made some slight changes (aside from recalibration) to the code but it’s mainly remained the same. Nowadays, I (team’s lead programmer) have more expertise and want to understand what’s going on here. Swerve is MK4i, double SparkMax/Neo V1.1, CanCoder.

Our code is at GitHub - FIREBOTICS/SwerveBot: Basic Swerve Chassis It’s mostly copied from GitHub - LoganKippnick/2023-MK4i-Neo-Swerve-Template I have made some modifications to the code since the last commit but they’re all pretty minor.

Here’s my question : why is the CanCoder referenced in some cases for the steer position, and why does it reference the Neo Relative Encoder in other places?

Line 85 and line 100 would seem to set the Neo Encoder’s output (modulo 360°) to be the same as the CanCoder’s°, but that isn’t the case, so either the math is wrong or I’m misunderstanding it. I tried changing line 195 (aka output) to use the CanCoder angle but it didn’t work (which in retrospect makes sense given the difference of angle between the two, and it also kinda looked like a miscalibrated PID ?).

The CANCoder is used to determine the initial absolute position of the module at startup to ensure correct orientation. Once initialized, the Neo encoder is used during driving (see on line 100, cancoder is used to set offset for the Neo encoder), this lets us use the motor controller’s built-in PID .

I’ve seen a couple different swerve code use this approach, I am currently using Advantage Kit’s swerve code and they do the same thing.

What are the advantages to this versus using the CanCoder in all places? Also, how does it work if the CanCoder’s output is accurate but the Relative Encoder’s doesn’t seem to be? [I suppose it’s possible I misinterpreted the data or looked at the wrong readings. Maybe a good idea to repeat the tests.]

It’s faster to just use the integrated encoder on NEO’s than to use the Cancoders for every call bc you dint have to reach out or wait for the cancoder value over CAN , you can just tell the SparkMAX to go to the position.

The SparkMAX has been seeded with the cancoder value so it should be the same thing, but with some slight drift.

Pure curiosity but have you considered YAGSL before making your own custom code? (Also a shameless plug)

Brought to you by Yet Another Generic Swerve Library (YAGSL)

posts.cooked:
Narnillian:

Maybe a good idea to repeat the tests.

Upon review, the encoders do indeed report the same angle and stay consistent, so maybe it’s about speed or efficiency?

nstrike:

It’s faster to just use the integrated encoder on NEO’s than to use the Cancoders for every call bc you dint have to reach out or wait for the cancoder value over CAN , you can just tell the SparkMAX to go to the position.

The code first gets the encoder angle to the RIO, then sends it back to the Spark. Is there a built in way to make it use the Relative Encoder internally?

Narnillian:

Is there a built in way to make it use the Relative Encoder internally?

Are you asking if there is a way to make the SparkMAX use the Cancoder as the feedback sensor in the SparkMAX Closedloop Controller running on the SparkMAX?

Not quite. The code we’re using calls getSteerEncAngle().getRadians() , meaning we actually are calling the Relative Encoder’s value back to the Rio, negating the benefits of a built-in encoder. Although, I’m not totally sure what calculateAdjustedAngle(double targetAngle, double currentAngle) actually does. I’ll look into YAGSL too.
